idpmodem Library Documentation¶

This Python (3.7+) library is a reference design for interfacing an edge device to an Inmarsat Type Approved modem designed to operate on the IsatData Pro satellite IoT messaging service.

atcommand_async¶

AT command protocol (asyncio) for Inmarsat IDP satellite messaging modems.

This module provides an async serial interface that sends and receives AT commands, decoding/abstracting typically used operations. Based on the AioSerial package.

Example usage:

import asyncio
import idpmodem

mymodem = idpmodem.IdpModemAsyncioClient()
initialized = asyncio.run(mymodem.initialize(crc=True))
class idpmodem.atcommand_async.IdpModemAsyncioClient(port: str = '/dev/ttyUSB0', baudrate: int = 9600, loop: Optional[asyncio.events.AbstractEventLoop] = None, logger: Optional[logging.Logger] = None, log_level: int = 20)¶

A satellite IoT messaging modem on Inmarsat’s IsatData Pro service.

port¶

The serial port name e.g. /dev/ttyUSB0

baudrate¶

The baudrate of the serial port e.g. 9600

crc¶

A boolean used if CRC-16 is enabled for long serial cables

loop¶

The asyncio event loop (uses default if not provided)

async command(at_command: str, timeout: int = 5, retries: int = 0) → list¶

Submits an AT command and returns the response asynchronously.

Proxies a private function to allow for multi-threaded operation.

Parameters

  • at_command – The AT command string

  • timeout – The maximum time in seconds to await a response.

  • retries – Optional number of additional attempts on failure.

Returns

A list of response strings finishing with ‘OK’, or

[‘ERROR’, ‘<error_code>’]

Raises

  • AtException if no response was received. –

  • AtException if bad CRC response count exceeds retries –

async config_crc_enable(crc: bool) → bool¶

Enables or disables CRC error checking (for long serial cable).

Parameters

crc – enable CRC if true

async config_report() → Tuple[dict, dict]¶

Sends the AT&V command to retrive S-register settings.

Returns

A tuple with two dictionaries or both None if failed at_config with booleans crc, echo, quiet and verbose reg_config with S-register tags and integer values

async config_restore_factory() → bool¶

Sends the AT&F command and returns True on success.

async config_restore_nvm() → bool¶

Sends the ATZ command to restore from non-volatile memory.

Returns

Boolean success.

async config_save() → bool¶

Sends the AT&W command and returns True if successful.

Sets the GNSS continous mode (0 = on-demand).

Parameters

  • doppler – Often required for moving assets.

Returns

True if successful setting.

async gnss_nmea_get(stale_secs: int = 1, wait_secs: int = 35, sentences: list = ['RMC', 'GSA', 'GGA', 'GSV']) → Union[list, str]¶

Returns a list of NMEA-formatted sentences from GNSS.

Parameters

  • stale_secs – Maximum age of fix in seconds (1..600)

  • wait_secs – Maximum time to wait for fix (1..600)

  • sentences – Optional list of NMEA sentence types to get

Returns

List of NMEA sentences

Raises

  • ValueError if parameter out of range –

  • AtGnssTimeout if no response from GNSS –

  • AtException –

Parameters

crc – desired initial CRC enabled if True

Returns

True if successful

Raises

async message_mt_get(name: str, data_format: int = 3, verbose: bool = True) → Union[dict, bytes]¶

Returns the payload of a specified mobile-terminated message.

Payload is presented as a string with encoding based on data_format.

Parameters

  • name – The unique name in the modem queue e.g. FM01.01

  • data_format – text=1, hex=2, base64=3 (default)

  • verbose – if True returns a dictionary, otherwise raw payload bytes

Returns

The encoded data as a string

Raises

AtException –

aterror¶

Base classes for AT command errors.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtBusy¶

The modem is busy processing a prior AT command.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtCrcConfigError¶

Indicates a CRC response was received when none expected or vice versa.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtCrcError¶

Indicates a detected CRC mismatch on a response.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtException¶

Base class for AT command exceptions.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtGnssTimeout¶

Indicates a timeout waiting for a GNSS fix.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtTimeout¶

Indicates a timeout waiting for response.

exception idpmodem.aterror.AtUnsolicited¶

Indicates unsolicited data was received from the modem.

nmea¶

Utilities for validating and parsing NMEA data into a Location object.

class idpmodem.nmea.Location(latitude=90.0, longitude=180.0, altitude=0.0, speed=0.0, heading=0.0, timestamp=0, satellites=0, fix_type=1)¶

A set of location-based information for a given point in time.

Uses 90.0/180.0 if latitude/longitude are unknown

latitude¶

decimal degrees

longitude¶

decimal degrees

altitude¶

in metres

speed¶

in knots

heading¶

in degrees

timestamp¶

in seconds since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z

satellites¶

in view at time of fix

fix_type¶

1=None, 2=2D or 3=3D

pdop¶

Probability Dilution of Precision

hdop¶

Horizontal Dilution of Precision

vdop¶

Vertical Dilution of Precision

time_iso¶

ISO 8601 formatted timestamp

satellites_info¶

GnssSatelliteInfo

elevation¶

The satellite elevation

The satellite azimuth

snr¶

The satellite Signal-to-Noise Ratio

exception idpmodem.nmea.NmeaChecksumError¶

NMEA sentence checksum error.

exception idpmodem.nmea.NmeaException¶

An exception triggered during NMEA sentence parsing.

exception idpmodem.nmea.NmeaInvalid¶

Invalid NMEA sentence.

idpmodem.nmea.validate_nmea_checksum(sentence: str) → Tuple[bool, str]¶

Validates NMEA sentence using checksum according to the standard.

Parameters

sentence – NMEA sentence including checksum

Returns

A tuple with Boolean result (checksum correct) and raw NMEA data string, with prefix $Gx and checksum suffix removed

message¶

Message classes for abstracting messages presented by/to the AT commands.

class idpmodem.message.Message(payload, name: Optional[str] = None, msg_sin: Optional[int] = None, msg_min: Optional[int] = None, priority: int = 4, data_format: int = 2, size: Optional[int] = None, logger: Optional[logging.Logger] = None, debug: bool = False)¶

Class intended for abstracting message attributes.

Parameters

  • payload –

    one of the following:

    • (bytearray) including SIN and MIN bytes as first 2 in the array if not explicitly set in the call

    • (list) of integer bytes (0..255) including SIN and MIN if not specified explicitly in the call

    • (string) ASCII-HEX which includes SIN and MIN if not specified explicitly in the call

    • (string) Text which requires both SIN and MIN explictly specified in the call

  • name – (string) optional up to 8 characters. A message name will be generated if not supplied

  • msg_sin – integer (0..255)

  • msg_min – integer (0..255)

  • priority – (1=high, 4=low, 0=mobile-terminated)

  • data_format – (optional) 1=FORMAT_TEXT, 2=FORMAT_HEX, 3=FORMAT_B64

  • log – (optional) logger object

  • debug – (optional) sets logging level to DEBUG

data(data_format=2, include_min=True, include_sin=False)¶

Returns the data content of the message

Parameters

  • data_format – (int) 1=FORMAT_TEXT, 2=FORMAT_HEX (default), 3=FORMAT_B64

  • include_min – (boolean) whether to include MIN byte in the data (used when not specifying MIN explicitly)

  • include_sin – (boolean) whether to include SIN byte (not part of data for MO messages)

Returns

data as a string for submission using AT%MGRT

class idpmodem.message.MobileOriginatedMessage(payload, name=None, data_format=2, msg_sin=None, msg_min=None, **kwargs)¶

Subclass of Message containing Mobile Originated (aka Return) message properties. Mobile-Originated state (starting=None) is represented as an attribute:

  • UNAVAILABLE: 0

  • TX_READY: 4

  • TX_SENDING: 5

  • TX_COMPLETE: 6

  • TX_FAILED: 7

Parameters

  • name – (string) user identifier for the message

  • payload – follows the structure of the Message superclass

  • data_format – follows the structure of the Message superclass

  • msg_sin – Service Identification Number (1st byte of payload)

  • msg_min – Message Identification Number (2nd byte of payload)

  • kwargs – follows the structure of the Message superclass

class idpmodem.message.MobileTerminatedMessage(payload, name, data_format, msg_num=None, priority=0, **kwargs)¶

Subclass of Message containing Mobile-Terminated (MT aka Forward) message properties. Initializes MT message with state = RX_RETRIEVED MT message state represented as an attribute:

  • UNAVAILABLE: 0

  • COMPLETE: 2

  • RETRIEVED: 3

Parameters

  • name – (string) name assigned by the modem

  • payload – follows the structure of the Message superclass

  • data_format – follows the structure of the Message superclass

  • msg_num – (string) message number assigned by the modem (unused)

  • priority – (int) always 0 for MT messages

  • kwargs – follows the structure of the Message superclass

Codec functions for IDP Common Message Format supported by Inmarsat MGS.

utils¶

Helpers for operating a headless device for example Raspberry Pi.

class idpmodem.utils.RepeatingTimer(seconds: int, target: Callable, args: Tuple = (), kwargs: dict = {}, name: Optional[str] = None, logger: Optional[logging.Logger] = None, log_level: int = 20, sleep_chunk: float = 0.25, max_drift: Optional[int] = None, auto_start: bool = False, defer: bool = True, debug: bool = False, daemon=True)¶

A repeating thread to call a function, can be stopped/restarted/changed.

Embedded tasks can use threading for continuous repeated operations. A RepeatingTimer can be started, stopped, restarted and reconfigured.

A Thread that counts down seconds using sleep increments, then calls back to a function with any provided arguments. Optional auto_start feature starts the thread and the timer, in this case the user doesn’t need to explicitly start() then start_timer().

name¶

An optional descriptive name for the Thread.

Type

str

interval¶

Repeating timer interval in seconds (0=disabled).

Type

int

sleep_chunk¶

The fraction of seconds between processing ticks.

Type

float

change_interval(seconds: int)¶

Change the timer interval and restart it.

Parameters

seconds (int) – The new interval in seconds.

Raises

ValueError if seconds is not an integer. –

join()¶

Wait until the thread terminates.

This blocks the calling thread until the thread whose join() method is called terminates – either normally or through an unhandled exception or until the optional timeout occurs.

When the timeout argument is present and not None, it should be a floating point number specifying a timeout for the operation in seconds (or fractions thereof). As join() always returns None, you must call is_alive() after join() to decide whether a timeout happened – if the thread is still alive, the join() call timed out.

When the timeout argument is not present or None, the operation will block until the thread terminates.

A thread can be join()ed many times.

join() raises a RuntimeError if an attempt is made to join the current thread as that would cause a deadlock. It is also an error to join() a thread before it has been started and attempts to do so raises the same exception.

restart_timer()¶

Restart the repeating timer (after an interval change).

run()¶

Note: runs automatically, not meant to be called explicitly.

Counts down the interval, checking every sleep_chunk for expiry.

start_timer()¶

Initially start the repeating timer.

stop_timer()¶

Stop the repeating timer.

terminate()¶

Terminate the timer. (Cannot be restarted)

idpmodem.utils.get_wrapping_logger(name: Optional[str] = None, filename: Optional[str] = None, file_size: int = 5, max_files: int = 2, debug: bool = False, log_level: int = 20, **kwargs) → logging.Logger¶

Sets up a wrapping logger that writes to console and optionally a file.

Logging is crucial for debugging embedded systems. However you don’t want to fill up an embedded drive with log files, so a wrapping_logger is useful that:

  • Initializes logging to console, and optionally a CSV formatted file

  • Log file wraps at a given maximum size (default 5 MB)

  • Is easy to configure a logging level (default INFO)

  • Uses UTC/GMT/Zulu timestamps

  • Provides a standardized CSV format

    • timestamp,[level],(thread),module.function:line,message

Parameters

  • name – Name of the logger (if None, uses name of calling module).

  • filename – (optional) Name of the file/path if writing to a file.

  • file_size – Max size of the file in megabytes, before wrapping.

  • max_files – The maximum number of files in rotation.

  • debug – backward compatible enable DEBUG logging

  • log_level – A logging level (default INFO)

  • kwargs – Optional overrides for RotatingFileHandler

Returns

A logger with console stream handler and (optional) file handler.
